abstracts.cdata!:
The Eritrea Emergency Reconstruction
            Program Project has a satisfactory outcome, is likely to be
            sustainable, and has a modest institutional development
            impact. The performances of both the Bank and the Borrower
            are satisfactory. The lessons cited addressed issues of
            design and implementation, the management of multi-sector
            operations and donor coordination, sector-supporting
            strategies and actions, and the needs of the poor and
            gender. Specific lessons included: 1) the need for projects
            operating in post-conflict countries to build in flexibility
            with fungible resources, accessed based on justification, to
            be able to address unforeseeable needs and conditions
            adequately, as they occur during implementation; 2) giving
            consideration to separating fast implementing and disbursing
            interventions for restoration of livelihoods and to address
            emergency needs, from interventions that may tend to take
            longer and have a longer-term development impact. 3) the
            importance of access to markets and services for any
            economic and social recovery process; 4) mainstreaming
            project component implementation and incorporating component
            design into the agency's strategic plan in order to
            facilitate internalization and enhance ownership and
            sustainability; 5) having smaller and more focused projects
            that involve fewer implementing agencies; 6) harmonizing
            procedures using the same manual of procurement as
            reference, and with central financial management using one
            MIS and with general management under one responsible
            entity; 7) the need to consult with beneficiaries in
            identifying and finalizing needs and areas of support in
            order to start-up and implement activities; 8) providing
            minimal support to displaced families as an incentive for
            returning to villages; 9) adopting design and build options
            for implementing emergency road infrastructure improvements;
            10) ensuring that emergency operations that target the
            private sector include interventions and monitoring
            indicators that address immediate needs for jumpstarting the
            private sector's contribution to the economy, and also
            build sustainability into project design by targeting
            export-oriented activities; 11) narrower targeting of
            criteria embracing the poor in particular, such as increased
            employment or income, to better focus assistance; and 12)
            targeting the needs of the female members of the communities.

6959138.trustfund:
TF027801-ERITREA EMERGENCY

repnme.cdata!:
Eritrea - Emergency Reconstruction Program
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The environmental assessment focuses on
            three main components of the Emergency Reconstruction
            Program Project: agriculture and the use of pesticides;
            housing program; and, private sector development. Potential
            environmental impacts, and the appropriate mitigation
            measures are: 1) provision of agricultural inputs, includes
            activities such as farm machinery for land preparation,
            pesticides and fertilizers, seeds, animal restocking, and
            water pumps for irrigation. While these activities will prod
            agricultural production, improper land management and
            pesticide uses, may induce declining crop yields, and soil
            fertility, and erosion, as well as genetic mutation in
            animals, and cancer, and other health issues on humans. Thus
            it is recommended to eliminate the use of chlorinated
            hydrocarbons in pesticides; avoid excessive fertilizer uses
            to minimize soil erosion, and water contamination; avoid
            importation of plant seed varieties, and animal breeds to
            preserve the local genetic pool, and, select the appropriate
            machinery per soil type, avoiding arid/fragile lands; 2)
            housing construction, and fuel wood collection inevitably
            causes land degradation and soil erosion; therefore, the use
            of corrugated iron sheet roofs, and masonry walls is
            suggested, as is the approach to village forest plantation
            programs, to re-vegetate, and maximize the efficient use of
            fuel wood, since it can not be avoided; and, 3) support for
            enterprise development, predominantly for micro, and small
            enterprises, hence no major environmental adversity is
            foreseen; however, institutional mechanisms should enforce
            environmental regulations, i.e., through the Department of
            the Environment.

5081747.trustfund:
TF034477-ERITREA - ECONOMIC RECOVERY CREDIT,TF027801-ERITREA EMERGENCY
            RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAM,TF040042-ERITREA - EMERGENCY RECOVERY CREDIT
5081747.majtheme: Rural development,Urban development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Reconstruction Project
            will assist Eritrea in the process of long-term
            reconstruction, and economic recovery, through the
            implementation of five sub-components: agriculture,
            infrastructure rehabilitation; private sector
            reconstruction, social protection, and, balance of payments.
            The main expected benefit is to mitigate the consequences of
            the ongoing humanitarian crisis, by providing assistance to
            displaced people, through agricultural inputs, grants for
            reconstruction of destroyed housing, and micro-finance. In
            addition, the project will lay the basis for long term
            recovery, by rehabilitating key infrastructure, initiate
            economic growth, and restore macroeconomic stability.
            Nonetheless, the risk of resumption of hostilities with
            Ethiopia still exist. Retroactive financing has been
            approved for the project, for expenditures made after June
            1st, 2000, and, full disbursement is expected by December 2002.
